conclusion: To find the magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity B, we use principles of magnetic force and equilibrium.
When the current I passes through the coil, the magnetic force on the coil is F = nBIL.
The coil is in equilibrium, so the magnetic force is balanced by the gravitational force of the weights on the right arm.
When the current is reversed, the direction of the magnetic force also reverses, but its magnitude remains the same.
To balance the system again, a weight with mass m is added to the left pan.
The force due to the added weight is mg.
This force must balance the reversed magnetic force.
The magnetic force when the current is reversed is F' = nBIL.
The gravitational force due to the added weight is mg.
Rearrange the equation to solve for B: B = mg / (nIL).
The magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity B is B = mg / (nIL).
